title: Office for Mission and Rector
description: Professional development centered around UD’s mission.

splash.title: Office for Mission and Rector
splash.alttext: A view of the Roesch Library's west entrance, looking up at the detached semicircle of columns next to the building.
splash.text: We educate for change, but our mission remains constant.

paragraphs: The University of Dayton was founded in 1850 and is guided by the Society of Mary, also known as the Marianists, a Roman Catholic religious order dedicated to education.

We at the University constantly seek truth and knowledge in our mission to improve the world. We strive to make the University a place where all are welcome, respected and supported. As a Marianist University, we are called to live and work together in community. We've built and nurtured the campus community. We invite and teach our students to do the same, and we ask each community member to learn, lead and serve.
That's the very essence of our faith and our academic pursuits. We believe that people who develop compassionate hearts and critical minds can transform the world.

At the center of the University's leadership, to enhance our Catholic and Marianist character, is the Office for Mission and Rector. Its role is simple: to form people and communities committed to our Catholic and Marianist tradition of education.

1. Participants will grow in familiarity with aspects of the Catholic and Marianist Mission
  2. Participants will engage with other UD professionals
  3. Participants will discover ways to integrate UD’s mission into their work and personal lives

badges.title: Marianist Tour Guide
badges.description: Congratulations. You did it. You visited some really important Marianist locations on UD's campus (and learned some great history along the way) without ever leaving your desk. You will be a tremendous asset at the next Marianist Trivia night. You know more about the places that tell the story of our rich Marianist history that hundreds walk past each day.

modules.title: Marianist 101
modules.description: If you have ever wondered what makes the Marianists distinct, this workshop is for you. We will explore some fundamental aspects of the Marianist Charism and how those influence the culture at UD. This workshop will be interactive and include time for discussion and questions.
modules.imagealt: Two students walking by a statue.
learningoutcomes: Understand the distinctive characteristics of the Marianist order and UD’s Marianist Mission.

modules.title: Meet the MEAs (and learn more about them)
modules.description: There are over 120 Marianist Educational Associates at UD! This workshop will feature a panel of MEAs who will share their experience and what being an MEA means for their work at UD. Whether you are interested in becoming an MEA or just want to know a little more about this program, this workshop is for you.
modules.imagealt: Mary statue with UD Chapel in the background.
learningoutcomes: Understand who MEAs are and how they contribute to advancing our mission.

modules.title: History of UD
modules.description: Back by popular demand, this interactive workshop will highlight some of the most important and pivotal moments in UD's 173-year history. If you are curious about how UD began, some of the trials and tribulations the institution has faced, or who some of our buildings are named after, you will find it in this workshop. As UD faces new challenges, we will see what helped UD respond to past challenges.
learningoutcomes: Discuss UD’s history, the challenges faced through the years, and the way UD can continue to adapt and change in the future.

modules.title: Exploring Service, Justice, and Peace in a Marianist Education
modules.description: One of the five characteristics of Marianist education is education for service, justice, peace, and the integrity of creation. In this interactive workshop, learn more about this characteristic and reflect on how you can incorporate it into your own work.
learningoutcomes: Discuss the many ways in which UD incorporates this aspect of Marianist Education into our curriculum and why it’s an important component of our mission.

paragraphs: Explore the Maranist Heritage tour videos and discover the significant places and monuments on the University of Dayton campus. The virtual tour is designed to help viewers unravel the stories and enduring legacies of these important places and monuments through these short, informative videos. Users who complete the tour and final reflection will be awarded the 'Marianist Tour Guide' badge. It's estimated that it will take no longer than 25 minutes to complete.

image.altText: Exterior lamp post with a decorative cross at the top and the University of Dayton campus unfocused in the background

paragraphs: We delve into the life and teachings of Blessed William Joseph Chaminade, who encouraged others to embrace contemplation and reflection in their relationship with God. He believed that amidst life's obstacles, one should flow like a brook, growing broader and deeper, overcoming challenges with patience and discipline. Serenity Pines, a sacred space on the university campus, stands as a tribute to Joe Bell, a devoted member of the campus community, who envisioned a place where students, faculty, and staff could find solace from life's busyness. Though Joe couldn't witness its creation, his dream lives on, commemorated by the names of those who have left their mark on the campus community.

The  "Mary at the Wedding Feast of Cana" statue beautifully depicts the pivotal role of Mary in Jesus' first miracle, as she instructs him to turn water into wine at the wedding feast. Commissioned by Joe Atman, a devoted alumnus, and his family, the statue stands as a powerful symbol of the Catholic Christian presence at U.D., drawing visitors closer with its inviting gestures and younger, active portrayal of Mary. Explore the  meaning and significance of this bronze sculpture, created by Robert Leppo of Leppo Works, in this informative video.

The Marianist Cemetery was established in 1854 during the cholera epidemic. The cemetery put in place through the efforts of Father Leo Meyer, the university's first president, and the Marianist brothers. When the Marianists acquired the property, they made a promise to watch over the grave of little Mary Louisa, the infant daughter of the Stewart family who died during the epidemic. This sacred site serves as a testament to the dedication of the Marianist brothers and their commitment to Father Chaminade's mission. Discover the unique story of Mary Louisa, the only female buried in the cemetery, and the evolution of the cemetery over the years.

The Hail Mary Monument is a symbol of devotion on the University of Dayton campus. Erected in 1904 when the university was still known as St. Mary's Institute, this statue honors the Dogmatic Proclamation of the Immaculate Conception of Mary on its 50th anniversary. Mary's profound role in the Catholic faith tradition makes her a cherished figure for the Marian family, and this statue, along with several others on campus, stands as a testament to her life, work, and service. Positioned near the heart of the campus, Mary's youthful and hopeful presence serves as a reminder of the library's vast collection of Marian resources, the largest in the world. Discover the history and beauty of this monument in this video.

Explore the captivating "Mary Seat of Wisdom" statue on the University of Dayton campus. Crafted by Marianist Brother, Joe Aspel, this sculpture portrays Mary in later life, representing her multifaceted roles as a woman, mother, refugee, widow, sister, friend, and companion. With hands raised in prayer, Mary invites us to share in her mission of bringing Christ into the world. As members of the Marianist family, we are called to embrace the Marianist spirit and mission, living with integrity and embodying the holiness that God invites each of us to be. Discover the meaning and significance of this monument in this video.

Welcome to the statue of St. Joseph and Jesus, a symbol of celebration for 100 years of the University of Dayton School of Engineering. This sculpture, located outside Kettering Labs, was generously gifted by Tim Beach and his wife Karen, and crafted by Marianist brother, Joe Aspell. Depicting St. Joseph and Jesus in a moment of play, the statue embodies the essence of engineering—a profession of hard work, dedication, and service to humanity. As we delve into the portrayal of St. Joseph as a protector and caregiver of Jesus, we witness the joy and playfulness shared between them, inspiring engineers to continue their noble work for the betterment of humankind. Discover the heartwarming story and significance behind this monument.

The statue of Chaminade, a tribute commissioned in honor of the 250th anniversary of Blessed William Joseph Chaminade's birth at the University of Dayton. Donated by President Dan Curran and Claire Renzetti, this remarkable sculpture captures Chaminade in his youth, full of energy and vigor as he begins his mission. Unlike other depictions, Chaminade's open hand invites us to join him in solidarity, offering an invitation to be part of his vision. With a book symbolizing the marianists' commitment to education and a simple satchel on his back, Chaminade's statue stands at the crossroads of the Central Mall, reminding us that life is a lifelong journey of choices, and we do not travel alone. Join us in this video to explore the  meaning and significance of this monument on the University of Dayton campus.

Discover the history and significance of St. Mary's Hall, one of the oldest buildings on the University of Dayton campus. Built in 1870 by Brother Max Zehler, then the president of U.D., it was originally called "Zehler's Folly" due to doubts about its size and cost. However, the Marianist's forward-thinking prevailed, making it the largest building in Dayton at the time. Over the years, St. Mary's Hall has served various purposes, from classrooms to a residence for the brothers, and now houses important administrative offices. The building is a living testament to the university's past, with historic photos adorning its walls and the original metal plates still on its steps, bearing the name "St. Mary's Institute." Join us in this video as we explore the rich heritage and enduring significance of St. Mary's Hall in the life of the University of Dayton.

Welcome to St. Joseph's, one of the University of Dayton's earliest academic buildings with a rich history. Originally dedicated in 1884, the building faced three devastating fires, the last of which occurred in December 1987. Despite the destruction, the statue of St. Joseph survived the flames, becoming a symbol of hope and resilience. Today, St. Joseph's serves as the academic home to social sciences like political science, sociology, and psychology, reflecting the university's commitment to the community. Discover the story of this remarkable building, from its role as a safe haven during the Dayton flood of 1913 to the university's ongoing commitment to its city, showcased in this video.

Now that you've visited the different Marianist locations on campus, you're invited to complete a short completion to receive the 'Marianist Tour Guide' badge. This activity will take less than five minutes.

lti.description: Complete the following Quick Write task.
lti.title: Complete Tour Reflection
